WRITING.TEXT: Does anyone know the timeline for Perez's return?

I think the first question is key: does administration know exactly what is going on in your classroom in regards to these gangs? Your admin has to be aware and you have to be clear with each other what is expected.
Secondly, you do have to have an understanding with the students about what this is all about for them. In other words, what is in it for them if they do well in your class? What is their incentive? Whenever I had gang members in my class, that was always the key -- they needed a reason to care about the class (English). What is the importance of your subject for life after high school? How important is a high school diploma? What will your course do for them? Otherwise, they'll always feel like they are just wasting their time. Sort of the same questions adult teachers ask at inservices. Everyone wants to know what is in it for them. If you feel like you're wasting your time, you'll act out. Teens are no different from adults in that regard.

Anything by Shakespeare dramatized by a full cast works much better than trying to just read the words off a page. Only problem is there are so many audio versions of his plays and they vary in quality -- it can be hit-and-miss on getting a really good one. Read reviews of that version first.

Same thing for me. Downloaded it onto my iPad and started reading, but as it is with digital versions, it can be hard to tell how long something truly is. It seemed I'd read for hours and barely make a dent.

Really couldn't get it the first time through, but now it is on the reading list for a Modern American Literature class I'm taking in the Spring, so I'm looking forward to tackling it again along with a bunch of other people.
Abridged versions are like the movie versions of your favorite books. They sometimes work, but they always leave something that you loved out.
